posts.title: Boris Karloff’s Thriller [Season 1]
posts.excerpt: Thriller (aka. Boris Karloff’s Thriller) was an hour-long TV Horror anthology series that originally aired on NBC from 1960 to 1962. Horror fans who grew up in the 1960’s and 1970’s were nearly enraptured with the content and structure of this show. Indeed, in his non-fiction book on horror, Danse Macabre, Stephen King calls Thriller …

posts._title: Tag Gallagher – The Third Man – Howard Hawks’ The Big Sky (2010)
posts.title: The Third Man – Howard Hawks’ The Big Sky
posts.excerpt: The Third Man – Howard Hawks’ »The Big Sky« Tag Gallagher’s 20-minutes fine video-essay from 2010 on Howard Hawks’ »The Big Sky«. It’s a slightly revised version of an essay which originally was made for the 2004-Kinowelt-DVD-edition of the movie. Its focus is character in Hawks’ movies. The essay mainly uses excerpts from »Big Sky«. …

posts.title: Harbour
posts.excerpt: About the movie While shooting “Flying over blue field” we lived in Bir�tonas sanatorium hotel. I was watching treatment procedures. People were plunging into bubble, mud and mineral water baths. They were going circles singing, were standing under cold water spouts. All this seemed like a sacred ritual, that frees from scurf of life. They …

posts._title: Aleksandr Sokurov – Sonata dlya Gitlera AKA Sonata for Hitler (1979 – 1989)
posts.title: Sonata dlya Gitlera
posts.excerpt: Set to the music of Bach and Penderecki, Sonata for Hitler weaves together a bank of images from German and Soviet archive footage, drawing out a psychological dimension from the historical landscape at the end of World War II. Alexander Sokurov’s Sonata for Hitler was banned by the Soviet authorities in his home country of …

posts.title: Flüchtlinge
posts.excerpt: Propaganda film detailing the plight of ethnic Germans, known as “Volga Germans”, in the Soviet province of Manchuria.

posts._title: Israel Cárdenas & Laura Amelia Guzmán – Jean Gentil (2010)
posts.title: Jean Gentil
posts.excerpt: Quote: In Jean Gentil, a man looks for a job in a cacophonous city that wouldn’t notice if he had never existed. He’s wearing a tie and the kind of sadness that removes from the face any immediately recognizable expression—the awkward and self-effacing sadness of the unwelcome immigrant. posts._title: Hiroshi Shimizu – Hachi no su no kodomotachi AKA Children of the Beehive (1948)
posts.title: Hachi no su no kodomotachi
posts.excerpt: The movie focuses on the plight of ten war orphans hailing from different cities across Japan. With nowhere to go, they scavenge around train stations, scratching out an existence by means of black market work for a one-legged tramp whilst avoiding being picked up by the police for vagrancy. Soon however, they find a more …

posts.title: Milestones
posts.excerpt: MILESTONES, Robert Kramer and John Douglas US 1975, 3 hours and 15 minutes, 16mm, B/W and color English This epic film represents an essential landmark within the political, intellectual and artistic entreprise of the 60’s and 70’s, following the Vietnam War. Milestones cuts back and forth between different story lines and features over fifty different …

posts.title: Collected HD Works (1970-1993)
posts.excerpt: William Raban is one of the foremost British artists and experimental filmmakers of the last forty years, known primarily for his landscape, performance and multi-screen based films. Born in Fakenham, Norfolk, in 1948, he went to St Martin’s School of Art in 1967, where he made paintings and prints that involved sustained but direct contact …
